posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313556
https://www.reddit.com/r/PS4Mods/comments/dnjuee/remap_ps_button_ds4_controller/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313558
My ribbon is damaged, im about to try adding wires from the PS button to the end of the ribbon just to get some electricity to and from. That's why I'm looking to switch the share function to the PS button. This kind of stuff is beyond my head, I'm new to tech stuff. I'm broke and I cant buy anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313556
If you only want to change those two buttons, you have two options.
1) change the mapping of the buttons on the PS4 itself (or your computer and emulator), you should be able to do that thru settings

2) Open up the controller and switch the positions of the wires for those two buttons. That way, pressing PS will send the 'share button' signal and visa versa. You probably need a sautering gun for this or at least a lighter

posts.com: How do I solve these? There's no two reactions that have an equal amount of reactant to the other, so I know that's not it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313525
For order of reactions

r = k . [A]^x . [B]^y (Eg. 1)

where r is the rate, k is the rate constant, x,y are orders of A,B respectively. If you don't know what [A],[B] means you are doing the wrong course and you need to go back to kindergarten

Use initial rates method since there's a column labelled initial reaction rate.

You need to take log both sides of Eq. 1

ln r = ln k + x.ln [A] + y.ln [B] (Eq. 2)

Then using values where one specie is constant or approximately constant plot a graph of
ln [Specie] vs ln r
which will then be equivalent to the equation

ln r = constant + gradient . ln [Specie] (Eq. 3)

Note that Eq. 3 has eliminated the other specie as it was invariant.

You should be able to observe that the gradient of Eq. 3 is equivalent to x,y in Eq. 2 and thus the gradient gives the order of the reaction for each specie.

You will find that one of the orders is about 0, the other about 2.

One of the constants from your two versions of Eq. 3 will be ignored for reasons you can explain out yourself. The missing rate is about 0.03 mol/L/s.


BTW I've never seen this before and I taught myself this in about 4 minutes of reading just now. I may have made a error but I don't think so because I back substituted my calculated rate constant and got good agreement with the reported rate which was not used to determine k or x/y. I can justify my answers but I'm not going to do all your homework for you.

All the justifying you will have to do yourself. For that you'll have to learn how to do this yourself. The mechanical details are able to be performed by idiot savants. You need to be able to explain the details to demonstrate that you actually understand.

I'm not going to come back to this thread so any further questions won't be answered by me. If I'm wrong, sorry, hope someone can steer you right. If I'm right, then you should have figured it out by now since you posted 4 hours ago.

>>1312374
underrated?
Arcanum of Steamworks and Magick Obscura
Lionheart
Neverwinter Nights (both 1 and 2) itself wasn't bad, but some of the expansion packs were really cool: HotU and Mask of the Betrayer come to the mind
i would say Jade Empire was pretty underrated too
Gothic 2 was kinda underrated too, partly because it's not from anglophone country and partly because of it's bad controls (those were fixed later)
Bard's Tale (2004) - it has only bare bones rpg elements, but it's extremely funny. I played it later than others when I found it has Android port (and it worked surprisingly well), so it even matches your mobile game criteria (though I played on tablet, today smartphones with their big displays would be definitely enough)
Another interesting rpg was Inquisitor, graphics was pretty bad considering the year it was made, and combat balance sucked too (I recommend playing on the easiest difficulty), but story, world and writing overall was really unique and brilliant
That's all i can think about underrated (even though some of them are known well enough, I don't think they got praise they deserved) rpgs from 00s.
As underrated non RPG or RTS from that time I would recommend especially Jedi Academy, I spent really lot time with that, but it was mostly multiplayer (and community it had) were it shone, also Serious Sam 2 is kinda underrated part of the franchise from that time.

>>1312374

Sub Culture (1997)

You play as a mini-guy in a submarine and you zap fish that are 5x your size, trade, do quests, fight pirates, explore deep sea caves, etc.

Tons of gadgets: missiles, mines, suck-o-matics (you use that to collect materials), drones, and so on.

Very easy to mod this game, also. The textures are literal .png files in the game's folders lol

You might need some tinkering to get it working on a current gen PC. Sadly I couldn't find any version with a working soundtrack, as it's stored in the game's CD originally (so using any no-cd fix will result in a no soundtrack experience AFAIK, kinda lame)

It's abandonware so you can find it for free online.

Intro: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sP7GDU8lR8

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

posts.com: Anyone know how transcoding works on video files? I want to upload a movie to streamable, but have it so it can be changed to different resolutions using the gear icon. Whenever I upload a torrent it’s just flat 1080p with no option to change. Is there any way to transcode on my end and then upload?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The domesticated rat is a surprisingly noble pet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313200
What you want to do is something the server handles, not you. You upload the best quality file that you want to share and then other clients will have the option to watch it at lower res if the server says they can.

If you have video A at 1080 then you re-encode it at a lower res 480 you now have a new video B. As far as the server is concerned, A and B are two different videos and cannot be accessed from the same link.

afaik 1080 and higher is for paid accounts only on streamable so contact their help centre. Also, wait. It takes time for the backend to transcode the video itself to make lower res versions available.

posts.com: I'm running a Tapermonkey javascript site theme for 4chan and I want to edit it to include a single instance where the text colour is not changed, which is what's being place there by 4chan X, namely the eye that shows me I have new (you)'s to peruse through (and now that I think about it, the threads themselves in the thread watcher). Whether they are excluded the the extent that they turn red, or even better, I can change the colour at whim of these specific instances, my browsing experience will be brought to new heights. Any ideas on what the code for this would be?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313010
I only use 4chan X so you'll probably have to do some work yourself, but I right clicked the red eye and clicked on inspect element, looked where the color was and copied that :root thing. Then I pasted that in the Custom CSS part of the advanced 4chan X settings, and added what was in the curly brackets (the color part). In your case you'd be adding that to your script (Oneechan?).

:root.yotsuba-b .replies-quoting-you > a, :root.yotsuba-b #watcher-link.replies-quoting-you{color: #F00;}

I changed the F00 to 0F0 and got the ugliest green, for example. Now you should be able to change the color and other stuff from whatever you want.

>which game should I start with and what should I expect?
Different guy but expect it to not be smooth sailing, you're not going to have the easiest time of things at first but stick with it and you'll get the hang of it and it's really damn satisfying once you do.
As for what game to try, purely from a difficulty standpoint 7 (Perfect Cherry Blossom, 8 (Imperishable Night), and 13 (Ten Desires) are probably the easiest of the windows games. They've each got a different feel to them music and aesthetic wise, and different mechanics as well but the basics are all the same. Also if you wanted to play the game a certain character is from then for the most part you can do that as well, there's only maybe four games I wouldn't reccomend starting with, and that'd give you perhaps a bit more of a goal to stick with.

posts.com:
I'll try go with shit I watched when I was young. I would say these would be closer to 7-8 than 4 but here you go. These are all based off their english dub form.

Medabots - personally didn't watch this until I was like 10 or 11 I think but I think dub is appropriate for that age range for the most part. There's one episode where the kids go to the bad part of town, and encounter some drunks that the dub tries to censor with it's spoken dialogue implying their possessed by ghost or something. It's comical as an adult because it's pretty obvious, but as a kid it flew right over my head. There's another episode where characters backstory is being from a country in a civil war. Nothing graphic is shown, or referred to but the implications are obvious an adult, but again flew over my head. These are only 2 episodes I can really find issue with though.

Digimon Adventure - watched when I was 5, and the dub definitely got away with some stuff I'm surprised flew back then. Lots of flashes to white when a human character gets punched or hit. There's also an episode where the main character gets slapped in the face by his mom in flashback. The dub kinda tiptoes around it by not showing the slap at all and cutting forward slightly after it happened, but the character is holding his face with a red mark while his mother berates him. Still blows my mind they got away with this. Otherwise can't think of anything else that bad in the dub.
Ronin Warriors is one I watched when I was 5-6 as well. Think power rangers but Samurai. Not sure if the holds up or really adhers to modern standard though

posts.com:
is it possible to take out just the subwoofer from a desktop speakers set and use it with full fledged speakers and a normal amp?

this particular logitech z323 set has a built in amp in the subwoofer so it already sounds like a complicated case to me. is it even possible?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1312761
Yes, in fact it's super easy because most receivers expect an "active subwoofer", which is effectively a large and expensive set of PC speakers with no speaker but the subwoofer. An active subwoofer takes input at line level, applies its own volume control and EQ, and provides its own amplifier. The only thing the receiver does is change the volume of the output, and handle the channel mixing if the source doesn't come with a .1 track.

Annoyingly the logitech set you're describing puts the controls and volume control in a satellite speaker with a proprietary connector, but the good news is that the connector is just a DB9, so you can easily cobble together a dummy speaker that's just a power switch and volume control.

In pic related, you'd want to remove the speakers, and send a mono signal to both inputs. The crossover is evidently still in the sub, and you don't want to confuse it by sending it a signal that's all the way to the left or right.
